name: Genius Invokation TCG
desc: Genius Invokation TCG is Genshin Impactâ€™s official card game, available as a permanent in-game mode that is unlocked at Adventure Rank 32.

value.name: Come Try Genius Invokation TCG!
value.desc: Someone in Mondstadt's alchemy store seems to be talking about a strange package they received recently. Go check it out.

value.name: Genius Invokation TCG
value.desc: A card game designed by two scholars from the Sumeru Akademiya. An Inazuman writer, Fukumoto, created a Genius Invokation TCG lore.

customize.text: Genius Invokation TCG is a permanent game mode within Genshin Impact. Players prepare decks of cards to battle in challenges against overworld opponents throughout Teyvat, as well as in duels against other players in Co-Op Mode.

<color=#ffffff>Base Requirement</color>
Reach Adventure Rank 32
Complete Archon Quest "Prologue: Act III - Song of the Dragon and Freedom"

In Genius Invokation TCG, Player Level is used to determine the difficulty of the challengers in Guest Challenges, the Lucky Coins rewards in the Sennight Gauntlet, as well as the availability of Character Invitationals, Tavern Card Challenges, and open-world challenges.
In order to level up, players have to accumulate Player EXP by:
Completing open-world challenges
Completing matches in the Sennight Gauntlet
The required Player EXP to reach each Player Level is as follows:

<color=#ffffff>Player Level</color>
<color=#ffffff>Required to reach this Level</color>
<color=#ffffff>Total</color>
1
N/A
2

customize.name: Player EXP
customize.desc: Obtained by winning Genius Invokation TCG matches. Every duel you won builds upon the paths to victory, such is the act of earning experience itself. To know how to overcome and subdue the adversary in any situation is the greatest strength that a player can possess.

customize.text:
At reaching the maximum Player EXP at Player Levels 2, 4, 6, and 9 (to reach Player Levels 3, 5, 7 and 10, respectively), you will have to complete an Ascension Challenge to continue leveling up. However, you may continue to earn Player EXP before clearing the Ascension Challenge - all earned Player EXP will be added to your Player Level progress after the Ascension Challenge.
Certain functionalities are unlocked at certain Player Levels:

<color=#ffffff73>Character Invitationals</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Co-Op Match</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Card Shop</color>
<color=#ffffff73>TCG Player's Manual</color>
<color=#ffffff73>All Player EXP-granting challenges in Mondstadt City</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Sennight Gauntlet</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Weekly Guest Challenges</color>
<color=#ffffff73>All Player EXP-granting challenges in Dragonspine Adventurer Camp</color>
<color=#ffffff73>+1</color>

customize.name: Match Invitation Letter
customize.desc: You can select a player from the Player List via the invitation board, and then entrust The Cat's Tail to send out an invitation using this Invitation Letter. The invited player will head over to the tavern and wait for a duel with you.

customize.text:

customize.name: Lucky Coin
customize.desc: Currency verified and used by the Genius Invokation TCG Society. Can be used to purchase various items related to Genius Invokation TCG. It is said that these coins were initially named as such in the hopes that they would bring those carrying them luck. However, perhaps it is those who are sufficiently lucky who are able to possess them...

customize.text:
Lucky Coins are the main currency of Genius Invokation TCG, and are used to purchase Match Invitation Letters, most Action Cards, and various Genius Invokation TCG cosmetic items.
They can be acquired by:
Completing the TCG Player's Manual
Completing open-world challenges
Winning Character Invitationals and Tavern Card Challenges on the Serious Showdown difficulty (for Diluc, Kaeya, Sucrose, and Fischl, also available on the Friendly Fracas difficulty)
Completing certain objectives in The Forge Realm's Temper
Participating in the Heated Battle Mode and completing certain objectives
Completing matches in the Sennight Gauntlet
Using certain redemption codes
While in a game of Genius Invokation TCG, you might select the gear icon on the top-right corner of the screen to select certain actions:
<color=#ffffff73>(PvE only) View the objectives that have to be met for rewards within the challenge.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Review the Genius Invokation TCG rules in-game.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Toggle certain game settings:</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Accelerate Duel:</color> <color=#ffffff73>Speed up the animations within the game.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Display Card Details When Opponent Plays:</color> <color=#ffffff73>Shows the detail of Action Cards the opponent plays as it is played.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Allow Friends to observe my duels:</color> <color=#ffffff73>Allow Friends to observe your gameplay (outside of Co-Op world invitations).</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Allow other players in Co-Op mode to observe my duels:</color> <color=#ffffff73>Allow players not in a game in the Co-Op world to observe your current game.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Forfeit the current game. Your opponent wins by default.</color>
While in-game, click the clock icon to view the actions that have happened in the game so far.

After you have received the Casket of Tomes, you may enable "Search for Players" in either the Inventory or the Map Settings to locate NPCs in the overworld that you can battle against for Player EXP and other rewards.
The invitation board located in the Cat's Tail allows players to access certain functionalities of Genius Invokation TCG.
Allows you to unlock and play Character Invitationals. Unlocking a Character Invitational costs one

customize.name: Match Invitation Letter
customize.desc: You can select a player from the Player List via the invitation board, and then entrust The Cat's Tail to send out an invitation using this Invitation Letter. The invited player will head over to the tavern and wait for a duel with you.

customize.text: , and unlocks both the Friendly Fracas difficulty and (at Player Level 7 or above, after clearing the Friendly Fracas difficulty) the Serious Showdown difficulty.
Allows you to play games with players in your world in Co-Op Mode, or play against others server-wide in Matchmade Duels.
When available, allows you to play games in the current Heated Battle Mode. Heated Battle Mode features limited-time variations on the Genius Invokation TCG rules.
Allows you to play Arena of Champions against others server-wide.
Interacting with Prince in the Cat's Tail allows players to access certain functionalities of Genius Invokation TCG.
Allows you to check your current Player Level progression and some other statistics, as well as claim Player Level and Ascension Challenge rewards.
Enter the Forge Realm's Temper Challenge.
Allows you to play the current Forge Realm's Temper Challenge.

Allows you to play Tavern Card Challenges. Each Tavern Card Challenge includes both the Friendly Fracas difficulty and (at Player Level 7 or above, after clearing the Friendly Fracas difficulty) the Serious Showdown difficulty.
Allows you to access the Card Shop, where you can purchase Action Cards, Character Invitation Letters, and cosmetics items such as Card Backs, Card Boxes and Card Skins.

View replays of your most recent games. You may view your 3 most recent games, and you may also save up to 5 of them to the Favorite Duels section. Replays in the Favorite Duels section will not be deleted.

After finishing the World Quest "Come Try Genius Invokation TCG!", players may invite others in their world in Co-Op Mode to play a game.
At Player Level 4, Matchmade Duels and the Arena of Champions are unlocked.

While outside of Co-Op Mode, instead of inviting a player in your world in Co-Op Match, you may opt to Match against another player from the same server. Players will be matched with another player at around their skill level using a hidden rating system.

In Arena of Champions, the objective is to win 5 games with a single deck before accumulating 3 losses. Once you start an attempt, you will be locked to the deck you started the attempt with (changes cannot be made to the deck at all) until you either win 5 times or lose 3 times. You may cancel an attempt at any point and start again with a new deck.
You can view records of your recent Arena of Champion attempts in the Arena Records.
It is possible to players to view others' games as they happen.

Players not playing a Genius Invokation TCG while a game is ongoing in a Co-Op world may observe the game by going into the Co-Op Mode menu and select "Observe Duel" on any of the players playing.
If your Friends have enabled the "Allow Friends to observe my duels" option, while they are playing Genius Invokation TCG (with the exception of playing against another player in their Co-Op world), you may observe their games by clicking Observe Duel on their profile in the My Friends list.
If a player has enabled the "Allow other players in Co-Op mode to observe my duels" option while they are playing Genius Invokation TCG in the same Co-Op world you are in, you may observe their games by clicking Observe Duel on their profile in the Co-Op Mode menu.
You may remove an observer from viewing your game by clicking on your own Avatar in-game and click "Remove Player" on the observer.

To allow or stop your Friends from viewing your games, you may toggle the "Allow Friends to observe my duels" option while in a game. Likewise, to allow other players in your Co-Op world to view your games within the world, you may toggle the "Allow other players in Co-Op mode to observe my duels" option while in a game.

Every week, you may earn up to a certain amount of Player EXP and Lucky Coins by winning weekly Guest Challenges, Matchmade Duels and Arena of Champions games.
Your maximum rewards cap for the week depends on your Player Level at the start of the week:

customize.text: <color=#ffffff40>*Rewards may not exceed the weekly cap; the excess portion from the cap will not be granted.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>At Player Level 2 and above, a new set of 4 Guest Challenges are available at the Cat's Tail every week.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>At Player Level 2/3, one Guest Challenge is available every day at server reset from Monday (all Guest Challenges for the week will be available from Thursday to Sunday).</color>
<color=#ffffff73>At Player Level 4 and above, all Guest Challenges are available on Monday at weekly server reset.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Guest Challenges' difficulty depends on your Player Level at the start of the week:</color>

<color=#ffffff>Player Level</color>
<color=#ffffff>Difficulty</color>
<color=#ffffff73>2</color>
Beginner
<color=#ffffff73>3 - 4</color>
Advanced
<color=#ffffff73>5 - 6</color>
Expert
<color=#ffffff73>7 - 9</color>
Master
10
Legend
Completing a Guest Challenge grants you 25% of your maximum rewards cap for the week.

At Player Level 4 and above, you may also complete the Sennight Gauntlet by winning Matchmade Duels and Arena of Champions games. Winning a game this way grants you 50% of your maximum rewards cap for the week.
<color=#ffffff73>After you have received the Casket of Tomes, within your Inventory, you can:</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Select "Search for Players" to look for open-world challenges.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Select "Deck" to enter the Deck List interface.</color>

On the Deck List interface, you may either:
Select a deck to set as Active Deck, edit its design, preview, copy or delete; or
Select a free slot to create a new deck; or
Import a deck using a Sharing Code.
You may also press and hold a deck, then drag the deck while holding it to quickly rearrange decks.

<color=#ffffff73>When you edit a deck or create a new deck, you will be placed in the deck building interface. Here, you can:</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Change the name of your deck;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Add cards to and remove cards from your deck;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>View cards' information, including text, Card Skins and story;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Filter cards by name or tags;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>View and copy the deck's Sharing Code;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Import and override deck using a Sharing Code;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Edit the deck's design.</color>
Here, you can change the Card Box and Card Back designs for either your selected deck, or for all decks that you currently have.
Note: Card Box changes will not apply in open-world challenges.
In Preview Deck, you can see all the cards in your deck at a quick glance, as well as view the deck's Sharing Code or export the deck as a sharable image (availability varies by platform).

Using a Sharing Code, you can share your deck to anyone so they can try out your deck without manually inputting every card into the deck. Unlike most code-based sharing systems in Genshin Impact, Genius Invokation TCG's Sharing Code system works across all servers, allowing decks to be shared no matter which server you play on.
A typical Genius Invokation deck consists of 3 Character Cards and 30 Action Cards.

<color=#ffffff73>Players may choose any Character Cards available to them for their decks. Each Character Card consists of</color> <color=#ffffff>HP</color> <color=#ffffff73>,</color> <color=#ffffff>Energy</color> <color=#ffffff73>,</color> <color=#ffffff>Tags</color> <color=#ffffff73>, and</color> <color=#ffffff>Skills</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>

The maximum health of the Character Card. In a game, a Character Card is considered defeated if its HP reaches 0.
(Note: if a Character Card's HP reaches 0 while it has an effect that ensures it " <color=#ffffff>will not be defeated</color> ", the Character Card is not considered defeated. Also see <color=#ffffff>will not be defeated</color> in Keywords.)
A Character Card's HP cannot go lower than 0.

The number of Energy points required to execute an Elemental Burst.
(Note: some Character Cards use a different unit in place of Energy. In such cases, the unit used will take the place of Energy).

<color=#ffffff>Element</color> <color=#ffffff73>: The Element that the Character Card is classified as at the time of deck building. This tag is used to determine the validity of Elemental Resonance cards.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Weapon</color> <color=#ffffff73>: The type of Weapon that the Character Card uses. This tag is used to determine which Weapon cards a Character Card can equip; Character Cards with the 'Other Weapons' tag cannot equip any Weapon card within a game.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Affiliation</color> <color=#ffffff73>: This tag is used to determine the validity of certain Action Cards.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Arkhe</color> <color=#ffffff73>(Fontaine Character Cards only): Used to make certain enemies</color> <color=#ffffff>Deactivated</color> <color=#ffffff73>. Currently only applicable in certain Adventure Challenges, and not in Duels.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>A Character Card will have:</color>
<color=#ffffff73>One or more</color> <color=#ffffff>Normal Attack</color> <color=#ffffff73>s;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>One or more</color> <color=#ffffff>Elemental Skill</color> <color=#ffffff73>s;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>One</color> <color=#ffffff>Elemental Burst</color> <color=#ffffff73>;</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Optionally, one</color> <color=#ffffff>Passive Skill</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
Action Cards can be categorized into three different types:

Cards that can be equipped onto a Character Card. Each Character Card may only equip one of each kind of Equipment Cards.
<color=#ffffff>Weapon</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that typically enhance the attack power of a Character Card, and may come with other effects. Each Character Card may only equip Weapon cards matching their own Weapon tag.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Artifact</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that give Character Cards certain effects.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that allow Character Cards to use Techniques in place of Skills.</color>

<color=#ffffff>Talent</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that enhance the base power of a Character Card. Talent cards are specific to each Character Card, and the corresponding Character Card must be in the deck for a Talent card to be valid.</color>

Cards that, when played, will stay in the Support Zone to assist in battle. These cards can have one of three tags:
<color=#ffffff>Item</color>

Cards with effects that take place immediately when played. Special types of Event Cards include:
<color=#ffffff>Arcane Legend</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that may have a major effect on the state of a game. Typically, each player may only play one Arcane Legend card in a game.</color>

<color=#ffffff>Food</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Cards that, when played, give the specified Character Card(s) the</color> <color=#ffffff>Satiated</color> <color=#ffffff73>Character Status. Food cards can't be played on Character Card(s) that are</color> <color=#ffffff>Satiated</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Elemental Resonance</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Special Event Cards that require at least 2 Character Cards in the deck with the specified Element to be added to the deck.</color>

<color=#ffffff>Talent</color> <color=#ffffff73>: Some Talent cards are Event Cards instead of Equipment Cards. The restriction on adding Talent Event Cards to a deck remains the same as with other Talent cards (the corresponding Character Card must be in the deck).</color>
Unless there are restrictions as stated on the card, Action Cards can be added freely into a deck, up to two copies per card (one copy per card for Arcane Legend cards).

<color=#ffffff73>Character Cards may be acquired by winning their respective Character Invitationals and Tavern Card Challenges on the Friendly Fracas difficulty.</color> <color=#ffffff73>(Diluc, Kaeya, Sucrose, and Fischl Character Cards are automatically given to you after the tutorial World Quest</color> <color=#ffffff73>.)</color>
<color=#ffffff73>All Talent Action Cards may be acquired by winning and completing respective objectives on the respective Character Cards' Character Invitationals and Tavern Card Challenges on the Friendly Fracas difficulty.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Most non-Talent Action Cards can be purchased with Lucky Coins at the Card Shop.</color> <color=#ffffff73>(Quest prerequisites may apply.)</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Certain copies of Action Cards can only be acquired through overworld Adventure Challenges or completing tasks in the TCG Player's Manual.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Certain Action Cards are not available through the Genius Invokation TCG system at all and must be acquired through another means.</color> <color=#ffffff73>(Currently, the Action Card</color> <color=#ffffff73>is the only card where this applies.)</color>

Due to the competitive nature of the game, cards may be adjusted at any time to maintain competitive balance. Balance changes are announced no later than when the servers are online for a new Version.
It is advised that players keep balance changes in mind when building and sharing decks, as a deck might not be the same after a Version Update.
Where Character Cards of each side are located throughout the game.

A display of your available Elemental Dice.
You may only have up to 16 Elemental Dice at a time. Any extra Elemental Dice acquired beyond this limit are destroyed.

Skills of the Active Character in play.
On your turn, you may select one of the available Skills, and play it if you have enough Elemental Dice to pay for it.

Where each side's Summons are located.
Unless otherwise specified, no two Summons of the same name can exist at once in the Summons Zone, and attempts to create a Summon with the same name will only refresh the existing Summon of the same name to its initial state.
Each side can only have up to 4 Summons in their Summons Zone. If a player's Summons Zone is full, any attempt to create a new Summon will be cancelled.

Where each side's Support Cards are located.
Unlike Summons, Support Cards of the same name can co-exist within the Support Zone.
Each side can only have up to 4 Support Cards in their Support Zone. If a player's Support Zone is full when they play another Support Card, they have to also destroy an existing Support Card in their Support Zone when they play it.

Where Action Cards are drawn from throughout the game, when prompted.
At any point within a game, you may select the Draw Pile of your side or the opponent to check the number of cards remaining in the pile.

The Action Cards that you can play.
You may only have up to 10 Action Cards at a time. Any extra Action Cards acquired beyond this limit are destroyed.

At the start of the game, each side draws 5 Action Cards from the Draw Pile into their Hand. (Arcane Legend cards are guaranteed to be drawn. If a deck has more than 5 Arcane Legend cards, they will be drawn randomly.)
Players may then choose to put any number of cards (0 to 5) of their choice back into the Draw Pile and draw that many cards from the Draw Pile into their Hand (a process commonly known as a "mulligan" in card game communities).

After that, both sides will secretly select their starting Active Characters, which will subsequently be revealed at the same time.
Round 1 starts after this procedure.

At any point in the game, each side will have one and only one Character Card to be the Active Character. You may only use Skills and Techniques of your Active Character within your turn.
Unless otherwise specified, all Combat Actions target the opponent's Active Character.
If at any point, you do not have an Active Character, you must select another Character Card on your side to be the Active Character. If you can't do so (in other words, all your characters are defeated), you lose the game.
A Round has 3 phases: Roll Phase, Action Phase, and End Phase.
Each player rolls 8 Elemental Dice. They may then choose to reroll any (0 to 8) Dice once.

Beginning with the player who ended the last Round (except on Round 1), each player takes a turn.
On each player's turn, they may make as many <color=#ffffff>Fast Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>s</color> as they want:
<color=#ffffff>Use Action Cards</color> <color=#ffffff73>(except for those with the</color> <color=#ffffff>Combat Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>keyword) for the Elemental Dice cost shown on the card; or</color>

<color=#ffffff>Conduct Elemental Tuning</color> <color=#ffffff73>by exchanging an Action Card in their Hand to convert an Elemental Die into one matching their current Active Character's current Element (dice already matching that Element, including Omni Dice, can't be Tuned); or</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Any other action that is marked as a</color> <color=#ffffff>Fast Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
They may then take any of these actions to end their turn:
<color=#ffffff>Take a Combat Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>by using any of the Character Card's</color> <color=#ffd780>Skill</color> <color=#ffffff73>s (not counting Passive Skills), a</color> <color=#ffd780>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>, or playing an Action Card that has the</color> <color=#ffffff>Combat Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>keyword, for the Elemental Dice cost shown on the Skill or card; or</color>

<color=#ffffff>Switch Character</color> <color=#ffffff73>to switch another Character Card in as the Active Character (unless it is done as a Fast Action, in which case it does not end the player's turn) for a cost of 1 Elemental Die (subject to change due to effects); or</color>
<color=#ffffff>End Round</color> <color=#ffffff73>to end their turn and no longer take any turns in a Round (effectively, "ending their Round").</color>

When a player ends their turn, the other player takes their turn. If a player has already ended their Round, the other player may take as many turns as they want before ending their Round. Once both players have declared End Round, the Round moves to the End Phase.

Summons, Statuses and effects that trigger at the End Phase trigger, starting from the player who ended their Round first. (Within the Summons and Support Zones, cards are triggered by the order in which they are played in their respective Zones.)
Then, each player draws 2 cards from their Draw Pile (or however many cards there are in their Draw Pile, if less than 2), then the next Round begins.

A player loses if all of their Character Cards are defeated. Typically, the other player is the winner.
A draw result can happen by:
Having both players' last remaining Character Cards defeated at the same time due to certain effects; or
Ending Round 14 with no conclusive winner.
In-game, all draw results are considered game losses to both players.

Genius Invokation TCG uses a simplified version of Genshin Impact's Elemental Reaction system, with some adjustments.
Note that, unlike in Genshin Impact, in Genius Invokation TCG, with the exception of Swirl and Crystallize, all Elemental Reactions are order-agnostic; in other words, the order in which the Element Applications take place does not change the effect of the Reaction.

customize.name: Elemental Reactions
customize.desc:
Elemental Reactions represent the centerpiece of the combat system of Genshin Impact. Understanding and mastering these interactions can drastically improve oneâ€™s proficiency in battle.

There are multiple factors to consider when triggering Elemental Reactions, such as aura, trigger, decay, etc. Elemental Gauge Theory and Internal Cooldowns will play a major role to help players understand the complexity behind Elemental Reactions.

customize.text:
When a Character Card takes <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> / <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> / <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> / <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> / <color=#99ff88>Dendro</color> DMG or Elemental Application, the corresponding Element is applied to the receiving Character Card.
(As in Genshin Impact, <color=#ffe699>Geo</color> and <color=#80ffd7>Anemo</color> cannot be applied to a Character Card with no existing Elemental Application.)
When an Elemental Reaction happens:
If it is caused by Elemental DMG, all effects of the Reaction will take place.
If it is caused by a non-DMG Application, only non-DMG effects will take place.

[ <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> + <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> ] / [ <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> + <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> ]
Deal +2 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.

[ <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> + <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> ]
Deal +2 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.
If the target Character Card is the Active Character, forcibly switch the next Character Card in to be the Active Character.

[ <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> + <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> ] / [ <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> + <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> ]
Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card, and deal 1 Piercing DMG to all other opponent's Character Cards.

[ <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> + <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> ]
Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.
The target Character Card receives the <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> status.
<color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color>
<color=#ffd780>Character Status</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Character cannot use Skills.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>(Lasts until the end of the Round)</color>
<color=#ffffff>When this Character Receives</color> <color=#ff9999>Pyro DMG</color> <color=#ffffff>or Physical DMG,</color> <color=#ffffff73>removes this effect and increases DMG taken by 2.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Note: Unlike in Genshin Impact:</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The Character Card does not retain</color> <color=#99ffff>Cryo Application</color> <color=#ffffff73>upon being</color> <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The "Shatter" Reaction (as it is called in Genshin Impact) does not work with</color> <color=#ffe699>Geo Application</color> <color=#ffffff73>or</color> <color=#ffe699>Geo DMG</color> <color=#ffffff73>, only</color> <color=#ffffff>Physical DMG</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>

[ <color=#80ffd7>Anemo</color> onto <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> / <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> / <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> / <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> ]
Deal 1 Elemental DMG of the non- <color=#80ffd7>Anemo</color> Element in the Reaction to all other opponent's Character Cards.

[ <color=#ffe699>Geo</color> onto <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> / <color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> / <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> / <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> ]
Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.
Gain 1 <color=#ece5d8>Crystallize</color> point.
<color=#ece5d8>Crystallize</color>
<color=#ffd780>Team Combat Status</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Grants 1</color> <color=#ffffff>Shield</color> <color=#ffffff73>point to your active character. (Can stack. Max 2 points.)</color>

[ <color=#99ff88>Dendro</color> + <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> ]
Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.
Create a <color=#ece5d8>Burning Flame</color> .
<color=#ece5d8>Burning Flame</color>
<color=#ffd780>Summon</color>
<color=#ffffff>End Phase:</color> Deal 1 <color=#ff9999>Pyro DMG</color> .
<color=#ffffff>Usage(s): 1</color> (Can stack. Max 2 stacks.)

<color=#ffffff73>Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Create a</color> <color=#ece5d8>Dendro Core</color> <color=#ffffff73>if it is not on your side.</color>
<color=#ece5d8>Dendro Core</color>
<color=#ffd780>Team Combat Status</color>
<color=#ffffff>When you deal</color> <color=#ff9999>Pyro DMG</color> <color=#ffffff>or</color> <color=#ffacff>Electro DMG</color> <color=#ffffff>to an opposing active character,</color> <color=#ffffff73>DMG dealt +2.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Usage(s): 1</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Deal +1 DMG for this instance to the target Character Card.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Create a</color> <color=#ece5d8>Catalyzing Field</color> <color=#ffffff73>if it is not on your side, or refresh its Usage(s) if it is.</color>
<color=#ece5d8>Catalyzing Field</color>
<color=#ffd780>Team Combat Status</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>When you deal</color> <color=#ffacff>Electro DMG</color> <color=#ffffffd9>or</color> <color=#99ff88>Dendro DMG</color> <color=#ffffffd9>to an opposing active character,</color> <color=#ffffff73>DMG dealt +1.</color>
<color=#ffffff>Usage(s): 2</color>

<color=#ffffff73>As</color> <color=#99ff88>Dendro</color> <color=#ffffff73>and</color> <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> <color=#ffffff73>do not cause a Reaction, when an Elemental Reaction of another Element is applied, it will react with the first Element Application applied to the Character Card that it can react with.</color>
<color=#80c0ff>Hydro</color> <color=#ffffff73>/</color> <color=#ff9999>Pyro</color> <color=#ffffff73>/</color> <color=#ffacff>Electro</color> <color=#ffffff73>will react with</color> <color=#99ff88>Dendro</color> <color=#ffffff73>if it was the first Element applied to the Character Card, and likewise with</color> <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
<color=#80ffd7>Anemo</color> <color=#ffffff73>/</color> <color=#ffe699>Geo</color> <color=#ffffff73>will only react with</color> <color=#99ffff>Cryo</color> <color=#ffffff73>, regardless of order.</color>
There are two types of games you will encounter in Genius Invokation TCG: Duels and Adventure Challenges. Each type of game has slightly different mechanics.

All games from the invitation board in the Cat's Tail (including Character Invitationals, Co-Op Match, Arena of Champions, and Heated Battle Mode variations, excluding Automatic Artistry) as well as certain Tavern Card Challenges, Guest Challenges, and open-world challenges, are Duels.
In a Duel, the opponent will play under the same conditions as you, with their own deck, Hand, Draw Pile, and Elemental Dice allocation. Special conditions may also apply depending on the mode.
In Co-Op games (including Co-Op Match, Arena of Champions, and Heated Battle Mode variations excluding Automatic Artistry), a timer also applies. If a player runs out of time on their turn in the Action Phase, they immediately end their Round. If a player runs out of time on any other action (e.g. selecting a new Active Character when it's the opponent's turn), that action ends and, if applicable, a random choice is made for the player.

Most Tavern Card Challenges, Guest Challenges, and open-world challenges are Adventure Challenges.
In Adventure Challenges, the opponent does not have a Hand nor Elemental Dice. Instead, they will use a set sequence of Skills each Round. You will be able to view this sequence of Skills through the use of the Intent system.

customize.name: Primogem
customize.desc: A primordial crystalline gem that's beyond the mundane world. Shines with the condensed hopes and dreams of universes that once were.

customize.name: Match Invitation Letter
customize.desc: You can select a player from the Player List via the invitation board, and then entrust The Cat's Tail to send out an invitation using this Invitation Letter. The invited player will head over to the tavern and wait for a duel with you.

customize.name: Lucky Coin
customize.desc: Currency verified and used by the Genius Invokation TCG Society. Can be used to purchase various items related to Genius Invokation TCG. It is said that these coins were initially named as such in the hopes that they would bring those carrying them luck. However, perhaps it is those who are sufficiently lucky who are able to possess them...

customize.text:
<color=#ffffff>Shield</color> points grant your Character Card defense. <color=#ffffff>Shield</color> points are not a standalone status of any kind, but rather are part of other statuses.
Unless otherwise specified, 1 <color=#ffffff>Shield</color> point negates 1 DMG (excluding <color=#ffffff>Piercing DMG</color> ).

Just as in Genshin Impact, most Character Cards require Energy to take out Elemental Bursts.
Unless otherwise specified, these assumptions are true for all cards that require Energy for Elemental Bursts:
A Character Card may only use an Elemental Burst when their Energy is at the maximum cap.
Normal Attacks and Elemental Skills add 1 Energy to the Character Card that executes it.
Character Cards that utilize a different system in place of Energy follow different rules.

An <color=#ffffff>Omni Element</color> al Die works as any and all other Elemental Dice. As such:
They can be used to fulfill any costs (Unaligned/Matching/specific Element).
They can never be used for Elemental Tuning.
If an Action Card, Skill, or Technique has an Unaligned Element cost, you pay that many Elemental Dice, regardless of Element, to use it.
If an Action Card, Skill, or Technique has an Unaligned Element cost, you pay that many Elemental Dice of the same Element (of your choice) to use it.

<color=#ffffff>Physical DMG</color> does not apply an Element to the opponent's Character Card, and thus will not cause an Elemental Reaction. However, dealing <color=#ffffff>Physical DMG</color> on a <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> Character Card removes that Character Card's <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> Status, with the target character taking 2 extra <color=#ffffff>Physical DMG</color> on that instance.

<color=#ffffff>Piercing DMG</color> can neither be amplified (by effects that increase or multiply DMG) nor be negated (by defensive or <color=#ffffff>Shield</color> effects). In other words, the number of <color=#ffffff>Piercing DMG</color> dealt to a Character Card will always decrease that Character Card's HP by that exact amount, bypassing all effects.
<color=#ffffff>Piercing DMG</color> does not apply an Element to the opponent's Character Card, and thus will not cause an Elemental Reaction.
If you have an even number of Elemental Dice at the time you use a Normal Attack, it is considered a Charged Attack.
If the Character Card has just been switched into play and the first Combat Action that the Character Card takes out is a Normal Attack, it is considered a Plunging Attack.

A <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> does not take place immediately; instead, it waits for a certain number of turns to be executed. If a player starts a turn while a <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> is being prepared and still yet to be executed, that player skips the turn.
On the turn the <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> is executed, it will be the only action that takes place that turn. The turn ends after the Prepare Skill is successfully executed.
At any point before the <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> is executed, if the Character Card whose <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> belongs to gets switched out of its Active Character position, the entire <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> will be cancelled. The <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> will also be cancelled if, by the time the skill is executed, the Character Card cannot use any <color=#ffffff73>Skills or Techniques</color> due to <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> , <color=#ece5d8>Petrification</color> or similar statuses.
Effects that trigger on the use of a Skill will not trigger on the use of a <color=#ffffff>Prepare Skill</color> .

<color=#ffffff73>A</color> <color=#ffffff>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>is a</color> <color=#ffffff>Combat Action</color> <color=#ffffff73>and can be used in place of a Skill by a Character Card that has the corresponding Technique card equipped. Using an equipped</color> <color=#ffffff>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>typically does not grant the Character Card an Energy point (or equivalent).</color>
<color=#ffffff73>If the Character Card cannot use any Skills due to</color> <color=#ece5d8>Frozen</color> <color=#ffffff73>,</color> <color=#ece5d8>Petrification</color> <color=#ffffff73>, or similar statuses, it also cannot use any</color> <color=#ffffff>Techniques</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>A</color> <color=#ffffff>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>is not a Skill.</color> <color=#ffffff73>Therefore, effects that trigger on the use of a Skill will not trigger on the use of a</color> <color=#ffffff>Technique</color> <color=#ffffff73>.</color>

When a card or status has an expiration time in the form of <color=#ffffff>Duration (Rounds)</color> , this value will go down by 1 at the end of a Round, and the card or status will destroy itself at the end of the Round when the value reaches 0.

When a card or status has an expiration time in the form of <color=#ffffff>Usage(s)</color> , this value will go down by 1 every time its effect is successfully triggered, and the card or status will destroy itself right after this value goes down to 0 (unless mentioned otherwise).

The act of willfully destroying a certain number of cards in your Hand using certain actions.
Note: Effects that count <color=#ffffff>Discard</color> ed cards or trigger on a <color=#ffffff>Discard</color> only trigger when cards are destroyed by actions with a <color=#ffffff>Discard</color> keyword. Cards destroyed due to Hand overdraw, replacements of cards on the Support Zone or Summons Zone, or cards used for Elemental Tuning do not count as <color=#ffffff>Discard</color> ed cards.
Elemental Tuning. This keyword is used as a trigger when Elemental Tuning is successfully executed.
Select one card from a specific number of cards. What happens after the point of selection is dictated by the action or effect that triggered the <color=#ffffff>Select</color> .

When a Character Card is defeated with an effect that ensures that the Character Card "will not be defeated", that Character Card will not be considered to be defeated, and all Statuses, cards, and Energy (or equivalent) points will remain intact on that Character Card. The Character Card's HP may be set to a certain value by the same effect.

Statuses that are attached to the Character Card. They are displayed on the Character Card that they belong to.
Character Statuses will be erased alongside the corresponding Character Card if that Character Card is defeated.

Statuses that belong to the entire team; i.e. all Character Cards on the side the status is on. They are displayed under the Active Character.
These statuses do not get erased when a Character Card is defeated.
